title: Efficient Chromosome Parallelization for Precision Medicine Genomic Workflows
summary: Large-scale genomic workflows used in precision medicine can process datasets spanning tens to hundreds of gigabytes per sample, leading to high memory spikes, intensive disk I/O, and task failures due to out-of-memory errors. Simple static resource allocation methods struggle to handle the variability in per-chromosome RAM demands, resulting in poor resource utilization and long runtimes. In this work, we propose multiple mechanisms for adaptive, RAM-efficient parallelization of chromosome-level bioinformatics workflows. First, we develop a symbolic regression model that estimates per-chromosome memory consumption for a given task and introduces an interpolating bias to conservatively minimize over-allocation. Second, we present a dynamic scheduler that adaptively predicts RAM usage with a polynomial regression model, treating task packing as a Knapsack problem to optimally batch jobs based on predicted memory requirements. Additionally, we present a static scheduler that optimizes chromosome processing order to minimize peak memory while preserving throughput. Our proposed methods, evaluated on simulations and real-world genomic pipelines, provide new mechanisms to reduce memory overruns and balance load across threads. We thereby achieve faster end-to-end execution, showcasing the potential to optimize large-scale genomic workflows.

AI.tldr: Large-scale genomic workflows face challenges of high memory spikes and poor resource utilization. This paper proposes adaptive RAM-efficient parallelization mechanisms to address these issues.
AI.motivation: The paper seeks to optimize large-scale genomic workflows that process massive datasets, addressing inefficiencies like memory overruns, long runtimes, and poor resource utilization in existing static resource allocation methods.
AI.method: The authors develop a symbolic regression model to estimate memory requirements, a dynamic scheduler using polynomial regression for task allocation, and a static scheduler to optimize processing order of chromosomes.
AI.result: The proposed methods effectively reduce memory overruns, balance thread load, and significantly improve the runtime of genomic workflows, demonstrated through simulations and real-world pipelines.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive scheduling and memory-efficient task allocation methods can greatly enhance the performance and reliability of large-scale genomic workflows.

title: Can Asymmetric Tile Buffering Be Beneficial?
summary:
General matrix multiplication (GEMM) is the computational backbone of modern AI workloads, and its efficiency is critically dependent on effective tiling strategies. Conventional approaches employ symmetric tile buffering, where the buffered tile size of the input $A$ along the dimension $M$ matches the output tile size of $C$.
  In this paper, we introduce asymmetric tile buffering (ATB), a simple but powerful technique that decouples the buffered tile dimensions of the input and output operands. We show, for the first time, that ATB is both practical and highly beneficial. To explain this effect, we develop a performance model that incorporates both the benefits of ATB (higher arithmetic intensity) and its overheads (higher kernel switching costs), providing insight into how to select effective ATB tiling factors. As a case study, we apply ATB to AMD's latest XDNA2 AI Engine (AIE), achieving up to a 4.54x speedup, from 4.8 to 24.6 TFLOPS on mixed-precision BFP16--BF16 GEMM, establishing a new performance record for XDNA2 AIE.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces asymmetric tile buffering (ATB) for matrix multiplication to improve efficiency, showing up to a 4.54x speedup on AMD's XDNA2 AI Engine.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to address the inefficiency of conventional symmetric tiling strategies in matrix multiplication, which are critical for AI workloads.
AI.method: They propose asymmetric tile buffering (ATB), decoupling input and output tile dimensions, and develop a performance model to balance its benefits and costs.
AI.result: ATB achieves up to 4.54x performance improvement, increasing throughput from 4.8 to 24.6 TFLOPS on AMD's XDNA2 AI Engine.
AI.conclusion: ATB is a practical and impactful approach to optimizing GEMM, demonstrating significant performance improvements and setting a new performance benchmark for the XDNA2 AI Engine.

title: Algorithms and optimizations for global non-linear hybrid fluid-kinetic finite element stellarator simulations
summary:
Predictive modeling of stellarator plasmas is crucial for advancing nuclear fusion energy, yet it faces unique computational difficulties. One of the main challenges is accurately simulating the dynamics of specific particle species that are not well captured by fluid models, which necessitates the use of hybrid fluid-kinetic models. The non-axisymmetric geometry of stellarators fundamentally couples the toroidal Fourier modes, in contrast to what happens in tokamaks, requiring different numerical and computational treatment.
  This work presents a novel, globally coupled projection scheme inside the JOREK finite element framework. The approach ensures a self-consistent and physically accurate transfer of kinetic markers to the fluid grid, effectively handling the complex 3D mesh by constructing and solving a unified linear system that encompasses all toroidal harmonics simultaneously. To manage the computational complexity of this coupling, the construction of the system's matrix is significantly accelerated using the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). The efficient localization of millions of particles is made possible by implementing a 3D R-Tree spatial index, which supports this projection and ensures computational tractability at scale.
  On realistic Wendelstein 7-X stellarator geometries, the fidelity of the framework is rigorously shown. In sharp contrast to the uncoupled approaches' poor performance, quantitative convergence tests verify that the coupled scheme attains the theoretically anticipated spectral convergence.
  This study offers a crucial capability for the predictive analysis and optimization of next-generation stellarator designs by developing a validated, high-fidelity computational tool.

AI.tldr: The paper develops a novel computational method for predictive modeling in stellarator plasmas to enhance nuclear fusion energy advancements.
AI.motivation: Stellarator plasmas face challenges in accurately simulating specific particle dynamics due to their non-axisymmetric geometry, necessitating advanced computational models.
AI.method: A globally coupled projection scheme is implemented within the JOREK framework, utilizing FFT for matrix acceleration and 3D R-Tree for efficient particle localization.
AI.result: The method demonstrates theoretical convergence and improved performance on realistic Wendelstein 7-X geometries for predictive modeling.
AI.conclusion: This research enables high-fidelity simulation tools crucial for optimizing stellarator designs, advancing nuclear fusion energy.

title: A Scalable NorthPole System with End-to-End Vertical Integration for Low-Latency and Energy-Efficient LLM Inference
summary: A vertically integrated, end-to-end, research prototype system combines 288 NorthPole neural inference accelerator cards, offline training algorithms, a high-performance runtime stack, and a containerized inference pipeline to deliver a scalable and efficient cloud inference service. The system delivers 115 peta-ops at 4-bit integer precision and 3.7 PB/s of memory bandwidth across 18 2U servers, while consuming only 30 kW of power and weighing 730 kg in a 0.67 m^2 42U rack footprint. The system can run 3 simultaneous instances of the 8-billion-parameter open-source IBM Granite-3.3-8b-instruct model at 2,048 context length with 28 simultaneous users and a per-user inter-token latency of 2.8 ms. The system is scalable, modular, and reconfigurable, supporting various model sizes and context lengths, and is ideal for deploying agentic workflows for enterprise AI applications in existing data center (cloud, on-prem) environments. For example, the system can support 18 instances of a 3-billion-parameter model or a single instance of a 70-billion-parameter model.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a research prototype system integrating advanced hardware and software to deliver a highly efficient and scalable cloud inference service.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to build scalable, modular, and efficient systems capable of handling large AI models with low latency and high performance for enterprise AI applications.
AI.method: The system combines NorthPole neural inference accelerator cards, custom training algorithms, a high-performance runtime stack, and an inference pipeline. It utilizes a compact hardware setup and efficient architecture to achieve impressive computational and bandwidth performance.
AI.result: The system achieves 115 peta-ops at 4-bit integer precision, supports multiple inference instances of large AI models, and delivers low per-user latency while maintaining energy efficiency.
AI.conclusion: The prototype demonstrates versatility and scalability, making it suitable for deploying diverse AI workflows and models in enterprise data centers while balancing efficiency and computational power.

title: CIMinus: Empowering Sparse DNN Workloads Modeling and Exploration on SRAM-based CIM Architectures
comment: 14 pages, 12 figures, accepted by IEEE Transactions on Computers
summary: Compute-in-memory (CIM) has emerged as a pivotal direction for accelerating workloads in the field of machine learning, such as Deep Neural Networks (DNNs). However, the effective exploitation of sparsity in CIM systems presents numerous challenges, due to the inherent limitations in their rigid array structures. Designing sparse DNN dataflows and developing efficient mapping strategies also become more complex when accounting for diverse sparsity patterns and the flexibility of a multi-macro CIM structure. Despite these complexities, there is still an absence of a unified systematic view and modeling approach for diverse sparse DNN workloads in CIM systems. In this paper, we propose CIMinus, a framework dedicated to cost modeling for sparse DNN workloads on CIM architectures. It provides an in-depth energy consumption analysis at the level of individual components and an assessment of the overall workload latency. We validate CIMinus against contemporary CIM architectures and demonstrate its applicability in two use-cases. These cases provide valuable insights into both the impact of sparsity patterns and the effectiveness of mapping strategies, bridging the gap between theoretical design and practical implementation.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces CIMinus, a framework for cost modeling of sparse DNN workloads in Compute-in-Memory (CIM) architectures, focusing on energy efficiency and workload latency.
AI.motivation: Current CIM systems face challenges utilizing sparsity in DNN workloads due to rigid array structures and complex sparse dataflows, with no unified modeling approach available.
AI.method: The authors propose CIMinus, a framework for analyzing energy and latency of sparse DNN workloads in CIM systems, validated on contemporary architectures with practical use-cases.
AI.result: CIMinus provides insights on the impact of sparsity patterns and mapping strategies, demonstrating its effectiveness in bridging the gap between theory and practical CIM applications.
AI.conclusion: CIMinus is shown to be an effective tool for understanding and optimizing sparse DNN workload performance in CIM systems, aiding in both design and implementation improvements.

title: Scenario-Aware Control of Segmented Ladder Bus: Design and FPGA Implementation
summary: Large-scale neuromorphic architectures consist of computing tiles that communicate spikes using a shared interconnect. The communication patterns in these systems are inherently sparse, asynchronous, and localized, as neural activity is characterized by temporal sparsity with occasional bursts of high traffic. These characteristics require optimized interconnects to handle high-activity bursts while consuming minimal power during idle periods. Among the proposed interconnect solutions, the dynamic segmented bus has gained attention due to its structural simplicity, scalability, and energy efficiency. Since the benefits of a dynamic segmented bus stem from its simplicity, it is essential to develop a streamlined control plane that can scale efficiently with the network. In this paper, we present a design methodology for a scenario-aware control plane tailored to a segmented ladder bus, with the aim of minimizing control overhead and optimizing energy and area utilization. We evaluated our approach using a combination of FPGA implementation and software simulation to assess scalability. The results demonstrated that our design process effectively reduces the control plane's area footprint compared to the data plane while maintaining scalability with network size.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a design methodology for a scalable and energy-efficient control plane tailored to a segmented ladder bus in neuromorphic architectures.
AI.motivation: Optimizing interconnects in neuromorphic architectures is necessary due to neural activity's sparse and high-burst communication patterns, requiring minimal power during idle and efficient handling during high traffic.
AI.method: The authors developed a scenario-aware control plane for a segmented ladder bus to reduce control overhead, optimizing energy and area utilization, and evaluated its scalability with FPGA implementation and software simulation.
AI.result: The proposed design significantly reduces the control plane's area compared to the data plane while maintaining scalability with increasing network size.
AI.conclusion: The design methodology enhances scalability, minimizes control overhead, and improves energy and area efficiency, making it a promising solution for neuromorphic architecture interconnects.

title: Gimballed Rotor Mechanism for Omnidirectional Quadrotors
summary: This paper presents the design of a gimballed rotor mechanism as a modular and efficient solution for constructing omnidirectional quadrotors. Unlike conventional quadrotors, which are underactuated, this class of quadrotors achieves full actuation, enabling independent motion in all six degrees of freedom. While existing omnidirectional quadrotor designs often require significant structural modifications, the proposed gimballed rotor system maintains a lightweight and easy-to-integrate design by incorporating servo motors within the rotor platforms, allowing independent tilting of each rotor without major alterations to the central structure of a quadrotor. To accommodate this unconventional design, we develop a new control allocation scheme in PX4 Autopilot and present successful flight tests, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a lightweight, gimballed rotor mechanism for omnidirectional quadrotors, achieving six-degree-of-freedom motion with minimal structural changes.
AI.motivation: Omnidirectional quadrotors often require large structural modifications, limiting their practical deployment. A simpler, lightweight solution was needed to achieve full actuation in all six degrees of freedom.
AI.method: The authors designed a gimballed rotor system that allows independent tilting of each rotor using servo motors. They developed a control allocation scheme in PX4 Autopilot and conducted flight tests to validate the system.
AI.result: The proposed gimballed rotor system successfully achieved full actuation in six degrees of freedom during flight tests, confirming its effectiveness and practicality.
AI.conclusion: The gimballed rotor mechanism offers an efficient, modular, and effective solution for constructing omnidirectional quadrotors, maintaining a lightweight structure.

title: Filling the Gaps of Polarity: Implementing Dependent Data and Codata Types with Implicit Arguments
summary: The expression problem describes a fundamental tradeoff between two types of extensibility: extending a type with new operations, such as by pattern matching on an algebraic data type in functional programming, and extending a type with new constructors, such as by adding a new object implementing an interface in object-oriented programming. Most dependently typed languages have good support for the former style through inductive types, but support for the latter style through coinductive types is usually much poorer. Polarity is a language that treats both kinds of types symmetrically and allows the developer to switch between type representations.However, it currently lacks several features expected of a state-of-the-art dependently typed language, such as implicit arguments. The central aim of this paper is to provide an algorithmic type system and inference algorithm for implicit arguments that respect the core symmetry of the language. Our work provides two key contributions: a complete algorithmic description of the type system backing Polarity, and a comprehensive description of a unification algorithm that covers arbitrary inductive and coinductive types. We give rules for reduction semantics, conversion checking, and a unification algorithm for pattern-matching, which are essential for a usable implementation. A work-in-progress implementation of the algorithms in this paper is available at https://polarity-lang.github.io/. We expect that the comprehensive account of the unification algorithm and our design decisions can serve as a blueprint for other dependently typed languages that support inductive and coinductive types symmetrically.

AI.tldr: This paper enhances the Polarity language by adding a type system and inference algorithm for implicit arguments, respecting symmetry between inductive and coinductive types.
AI.motivation: Dependently typed languages often favor inductive types (extending types with operations) over coinductive types (extending types with constructors). Polarity aims to balance this asymmetry but lacks features like implicit arguments.
AI.method: The authors propose an algorithm for implicit argument inference, comprising reduction semantics, conversion checking, and a unification algorithm for pattern matching across inductive and coinductive types.
AI.result: The paper provides a complete description of Polarity's type system and unification algorithm. An implementation is available, offering practical insights and serving as a model for other dependently typed languages.
AI.conclusion: This work enhances dependently typed languages by addressing symmetry issues with inductive and coinductive types and can guide future developments with similar goals.

title: Beat Frequency Induced Transitions in Synchronization Dynamics
summary: In neurosciences, the brain processes information via the firing patterns of connected neurons operating across a spectrum of frequencies. To better understand the effects of these frequencies in the neuron dynamics, we have simulated a neuronal network of Izhikevich neurons to examine the interaction between frequency allocation and intermittent phase synchronization dynamics. As the synchronized population of neurons passes through a bifurcation, an additional frequency mode emerges, enabling a match in the mean frequency while retaining distinct most probable frequencies among neurons. Subsequently, the network intermittently transits between two patterns, one partially synchronized and the other unsynchronized. Through our analysis, we demonstrate that the frequency changes on the network lead to characteristic transition times between synchronization states. Moreover, these transitions adhere to beat frequency statistics when the neurons' frequencies differ by multiples of a frequency gap. Finally, our results can improve the performance in predicting transitions on problems where the beat frequency strongly influences the dynamics.

AI.tldr: The study simulates a network of Izhikevich neurons to explore the effects of frequency dynamics and phase synchronization, revealing transitions influenced by beat frequency statistics.
AI.motivation: The researchers aim to understand how frequency dynamics affect neuronal synchronization and transitions in neural networks.
AI.method: Simulation of an Izhikevich neuronal network to examine interactions between frequency allocation and phase synchronization dynamics.
AI.result: The study finds that frequency changes lead to transitions between synchronized and unsynchronized states, with timing influenced by beat frequencies.
AI.conclusion: The results enhance predictions of transition dynamics in networks where beat frequency plays a critical role, offering insights into neural processes.

title: Technique to Baseline QE Artefact Generation Aligned to Quality Metrics
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are transforming Quality Engineering (QE) by automating the generation of artefacts such as requirements, test cases, and Behavior Driven Development (BDD) scenarios. However, ensuring the quality of these outputs remains a challenge. This paper presents a systematic technique to baseline and evaluate QE artefacts using quantifiable metrics. The approach combines LLM-driven generation, reverse generation , and iterative refinement guided by rubrics technique for clarity, completeness, consistency, and testability. Experimental results across 12 projects show that reverse-generated artefacts can outperform low-quality inputs and maintain high standards when inputs are strong. The framework enables scalable, reliable QE artefact validation, bridging automation with accountability.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework that uses Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate, refine, and evaluate quality engineering artefacts such as requirements and test cases, ensuring their quality using systematic rubrics.
AI.motivation: Improving Quality Engineering (QE) by leveraging LLMs for the automation of artefact generation while addressing challenges in ensuring the quality of outputs.
AI.method: The method involves LLM-driven generation, reverse generation, and iterative refinement of artefacts using rubrics for evaluating clarity, completeness, consistency, and testability.
AI.result: Experimental results on 12 projects show that reverse-generated artefacts can exceed the quality of low-grade inputs while remaining effective with high-quality inputs.
AI.conclusion: The framework bridges automation with accountability, ensuring scalable and reliable validation of QE artefacts.

title: Majority Rules: LLM Ensemble is a Winning Approach for Content Categorization
summary: This study introduces an ensemble framework for unstructured text categorization using large language models (LLMs). By integrating multiple models, the ensemble large language model (eLLM) framework addresses common weaknesses of individual systems, including inconsistency, hallucination, category inflation, and misclassification. The eLLM approach yields a substantial performance improvement of up to 65\% in F1-score over the strongest single model. We formalize the ensemble process through a mathematical model of collective decision-making and establish principled aggregation criteria. Using the Interactive Advertising Bureau (IAB) hierarchical taxonomy, we evaluate ten state-of-the-art LLMs under identical zero-shot conditions on a human-annotated corpus of 8{,}660 samples. Results show that individual models plateau in performance due to the compression of semantically rich text into sparse categorical representations, while eLLM improves both robustness and accuracy. With a diverse consortium of models, eLLM achieves near human-expert-level performance, offering a scalable and reliable solution for taxonomy-based classification that may significantly reduce dependence on human expert labeling.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes an ensemble framework, eLLM, leveraging multiple large language models (LLMs) for efficient unstructured text categorization, demonstrating significant improvement in F1-score and expert-level performance.
AI.motivation: Individual LLMs face challenges like inconsistency, hallucination, category inflation, and misclassification in text categorization tasks. A better framework is needed to enhance robustness and reliability.
AI.method: The authors introduced the eLLM framework that integrates multiple LLMs through a mathematical model of collective decision-making with principled aggregation criteria. Performance was evaluated using the IAB hierarchical taxonomy and a human-annotated corpus in a zero-shot setup.
AI.result: The eLLM framework improved up to 65% in F1-score over the best-performing single model and showed robustness and accuracy improvement while achieving near human-expert-level performance.
AI.conclusion: The proposed eLLM framework offers a scalable and dependable solution for taxonomy-based classification, with the potential to decrease reliance on human expert labeling.

title: Atlas Gaussian processes on restricted domains and point clouds
summary: In real-world applications, data often reside in restricted domains with unknown boundaries, or as high-dimensional point clouds lying on a lower-dimensional, nontrivial, unknown manifold. Traditional Gaussian Processes (GPs) struggle to capture the underlying geometry in such settings. Some existing methods assume a flat space embedded in a point cloud, which can be represented by a single latent chart (latent space), while others exhibit weak performance when the point cloud is sparse or irregularly sampled. The goal of this work is to address these challenges. The main contributions are twofold: (1) We establish the Atlas Brownian Motion (BM) framework for estimating the heat kernel on point clouds with unknown geometries and nontrivial topological structures; (2) Instead of directly using the heat kernel estimates, we construct a Riemannian corrected kernel by combining the global heat kernel with local RBF kernel and leading to the formulation of Riemannian-corrected Atlas Gaussian Processes (RC-AGPs). The resulting RC-AGPs are applied to regression tasks across synthetic and real-world datasets. These examples demonstrate that our method outperforms existing approaches in both heat kernel estimation and regression accuracy. It improves statistical inference by effectively bridging the gap between complex, high-dimensional observations and manifold-based inferences.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a novel Atlas Brownian Motion framework and Riemannian-Corrected Atlas Gaussian Processes (RC-AGPs) to improve regression accuracy and statistical inference on data residing in complex, high-dimensional geometries.
AI.motivation: Traditional Gaussian Processes struggle with data in restricted domains, complex geometries, or high-dimensional point clouds on nontrivial manifolds. Existing methods have limitations like weak performance on sparse or irregular samples, necessitating an improved approach.
AI.method: The authors developed the Atlas Brownian Motion framework to estimate the heat kernel on point clouds and introduced RC-AGPs by combining the global heat kernel with local RBF kernel, incorporating geometry corrections for enhanced performance.
AI.result: RC-AGPs demonstrated superior performance on regression tasks with both synthetic and real-world datasets. The method improves heat kernel estimation and enhances statistical inference by effectively representing manifold-based geometries.
AI.conclusion: The proposed methods address key limitations in Gaussian Processes for complex geometries, demonstrating their utility in heat kernel estimation and inference. RC-AGPs offer accurate, scalable, and flexible tools for real-world data analysis.

title: UniFit: Towards Universal Virtual Try-on with MLLM-Guided Semantic Alignment
summary: Image-based virtual try-on (VTON) aims to synthesize photorealistic images of a person wearing specified garments. Despite significant progress, building a universal VTON framework that can flexibly handle diverse and complex tasks remains a major challenge. Recent methods explore multi-task VTON frameworks guided by textual instructions, yet they still face two key limitations: (1) semantic gap between text instructions and reference images, and (2) data scarcity in complex scenarios. To address these challenges, we propose UniFit, a universal VTON framework driven by a Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM). Specifically, we introduce an MLLM-Guided Semantic Alignment Module (MGSA), which integrates multimodal inputs using an MLLM and a set of learnable queries. By imposing a semantic alignment loss, MGSA captures cross-modal semantic relationships and provides coherent and explicit semantic guidance for the generative process, thereby reducing the semantic gap. Moreover, by devising a two-stage progressive training strategy with a self-synthesis pipeline, UniFit is able to learn complex tasks from limited data. Extensive experiments show that UniFit not only supports a wide range of VTON tasks, including multi-garment and model-to-model try-on, but also achieves state-of-the-art performance. The source code and pretrained models are available at https://github.com/zwplus/UniFit.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces UniFit, a universal image-based virtual try-on framework driven by Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLM), addressing semantic gaps and data scarcity for flexible and complex VTON tasks.
AI.motivation: The need to develop a universal virtual try-on system that can handle diverse and complex scenarios, while overcoming semantic gaps and data scarcity limitations.
AI.method: The UniFit framework leverages a Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM)-Guided Semantic Alignment Module (MGSA) and incorporates a progressive training strategy with a self-synthesis pipeline.
AI.result: UniFit supports various VTON tasks, including multi-garment and model-to-model try-on, achieving state-of-the-art performance in experiments.
AI.conclusion: UniFit effectively addresses challenges in virtual try-on systems by utilizing MLLM for semantic alignment and progressive training, offering flexible and high-performing capabilities across diverse tasks.

title: Extending Test-Time Scaling: A 3D Perspective with Context, Batch, and Turn
summary: Reasoning reinforcement learning (RL) has recently revealed a new scaling effect: test-time scaling. Thinking models such as R1 and o1 improve their reasoning accuracy at test time as the length of the reasoning context increases. However, compared with training-time scaling, test-time scaling is fundamentally limited by the limited context length of base models, which remains orders of magnitude smaller than the amount of tokens consumed during training. We revisit test-time enhancement techniques through the lens of scaling effect and introduce a unified framework of multi-dimensional test-time scaling to extend the capacity of test-time reasoning. Beyond conventional context-length scaling, we consider two additional dimensions: batch scaling, where accuracy improves with parallel sampling, and turn scaling, where iterative self-refinement enhances reasoning quality. Building on this perspective, we propose 3D test-time scaling, which integrates context, batch, and turn scaling. We show that: (1) each dimension demonstrates a test-time scaling effect, but with a bounded capacity; (2) combining all three dimensions substantially improves the reasoning performance of challenging testbeds, including IOI, IMO, and CPHO, and further benefits from human preference feedback; and (3) the human-in-the-loop framework naturally extends to a more open-ended domain, i.e., embodied learning, which enables the design of humanoid control behaviors.

AI.tldr: The paper explores test-time scaling in reasoning reinforcement learning, introducing a framework of multi-dimensional scaling (context, batch, turn) to improve reasoning performance and open up new applications like humanoid control.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses limitations in reasoning accuracy due to restricted context lengths during test-time scaling in RL models and seeks methods to enhance test-time reasoning beyond conventional approaches.
AI.method: The authors propose a unified framework of 3D test-time scaling, combining context-length scaling, batch scaling, and turn scaling, alongside iterative self-refinement and human preference feedback mechanisms.
AI.result: The study demonstrates improvements in reasoning performance across challenging datasets like IOI, IMO, and CPHO, and showcases applications in embodied learning and humanoid behavior design.
AI.conclusion: Multi-dimensional test-time scaling boosts reasoning capabilities, expands applications, and leverages human-in-the-loop feedback for further advancements in RL tasks.

title: What Really Counts? Examining Step and Token Level Attribution in Multilingual CoT Reasoning
comment: Received the Best Student Project Award at RuG's Advanced-NLP course
summary: This study investigates the attribution patterns underlying Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning in multilingual LLMs. While prior works demonstrate the role of CoT prompting in improving task performance, there are concerns regarding the faithfulness and interpretability of the generated reasoning chains. To assess these properties across languages, we applied two complementary attribution methods--ContextCite for step-level attribution and Inseq for token-level attribution--to the Qwen2.5 1.5B-Instruct model using the MGSM benchmark. Our experimental results highlight key findings such as: (1) attribution scores excessively emphasize the final reasoning step, particularly in incorrect generations; (2) structured CoT prompting significantly improves accuracy primarily for high-resource Latin-script languages; and (3) controlled perturbations via negation and distractor sentences reduce model accuracy and attribution coherence. These findings highlight the limitations of CoT prompting, particularly in terms of multilingual robustness and interpretive transparency.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates the attribution patterns of Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning and its multilingual robustness in large language models (LLMs).
AI.motivation: The motivation lies in addressing concerns about the faithfulness and interpretability of reasoning chains in multilingual LLMs using Chain-of-Thought prompting.
AI.method: Two complementary attribution methods (ContextCite for step-level and Inseq for token-level) were applied to the Qwen2.5 1.5B-Instruct model using the MGSM benchmark for analysis.
AI.result: Key findings include: (1) attribution scores overly focusing on the final step in incorrect generations; (2) CoT prompting yielding better performance in high-resource Latin-script languages; and (3) perturbations reducing both accuracy and attribution coherence.
AI.conclusion: The study reveals limitations of CoT prompting in terms of multilingual robustness and interpretive transparency, suggesting room for further improvement in reasoning quality and understanding.

title: Optimizing Communication in Byzantine Agreement Protocols with Slim-HBBFT
summary: Byzantine agreement protocols in asynchronous networks have received renewed interest because they do not rely on network behavior to achieve termination. Conventional asynchronous Byzantine agreement protocols require every party to broadcast its requests (e.g., transactions), and at the end of the protocol, parties agree on one party's request. If parties agree on one party's requests while exchanging every party's request, the protocol becomes expensive. These protocols are used to design an atomic broadcast (ABC) protocol where parties agree on $\langle n-f \rangle$ parties' requests (assuming $n=3f+1$, where $n$ is the total number of parties, and $f$ is the number of Byzantine parties). Although the parties agree on a subset of requests in the ABC protocol, if the requests do not vary (are duplicated), investing in a costly protocol is not justified. We propose Slim-HBBFT, an atomic broadcast protocol that considers requests from a fraction of $n$ parties and improves communication complexity by a factor of $O(n)$. At the core of our design is a prioritized provable-broadcast (P-PB) protocol that generates proof of broadcast only for selected parties. We use the P-PB protocol to design the Slim-HBBFT atomic broadcast protocol. Additionally, we conduct a comprehensive security analysis to demonstrate that Slim-HBBFT satisfies the properties of the Asynchronous Common Subset protocol, ensuring robust security and reliability.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Slim-HBBFT, a more efficient atomic broadcast protocol that improves communication complexity in asynchronous Byzantine systems by addressing duplicated requests.
AI.motivation: To address the inefficiency of asynchronous Byzantine agreement protocols when requests are duplicated, leading to unnecessary communication overhead.
AI.method: The authors propose Slim-HBBFT, which incorporates a prioritized provable-broadcast (P-PB) protocol focusing on selected party requests to reduce communication complexity.
AI.result: Slim-HBBFT improves communication complexity by a factor of O(n) without compromising security or reliability in the asynchronous Byzantine agreement protocols.
AI.conclusion: Slim-HBBFT successfully optimizes atomic broadcast for scenarios with repetitive or duplicated requests while maintaining robust security and reliability in asynchronous networks.

title: Unsupervised Graph Neural Network Framework for Balanced Multipatterning in Advanced Electronic Design Automation Layouts
summary: Multipatterning is an essential decomposition strategy in electronic design automation (EDA) that overcomes lithographic limitations when printing dense circuit layouts. Although heuristic-based backtracking and SAT solvers can address these challenges, they often struggle to simultaneously handle both complex constraints and secondary objectives. In this study, we present a hybrid workflow that casts multipatterning as a variant of a constrained graph coloring problem with the primary objective of minimizing feature violations and a secondary objective of balancing the number of features on each mask. Our pipeline integrates two main components: (1) A GNN-based agent, trained in an unsupervised manner to generate initial color predictions, which are refined by (2) refinement strategies (a GNN-based heuristic and simulated annealing) that together enhance solution quality and balance. Experimental evaluation in both proprietary data sets and publicly available open source layouts demonstrate complete conflict-free decomposition and consistent color balancing. The proposed framework provides a reproducible, data-efficient and deployable baseline for scalable layout decomposition in EDA workflows.

AI.tldr: Multipatterning, a technique in electronic design automation, uses a hybrid approach with a GNN-based agent and refinement strategies to solve constrained graph coloring problems for circuit layouts.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the limitations of existing heuristic-based and SAT solver methods in handling complex constraints and optimizing secondary objectives in multipatterning for electronic design.
AI.method: The hybrid workflow involves a GNN-based agent for unsupervised color predictions, refined through additional GNN-based heuristics and simulated annealing.
AI.result: The proposed framework achieves conflict-free decomposition and balanced color assignments on both proprietary and open-source circuit layouts.
AI.conclusion: This approach offers a scalable, data-efficient, reproducible, and deployable solution for layout decomposition in electronic design automation processes.

title: Neuromorphic Astronomy: An End-to-End SNN Pipeline for RFI Detection Hardware
summary: Imminent radio telescope observatories provide massive data rates making deep learning based processing appealing while simultaneously demanding real-time performance at low-energy; prohibiting the use of many artificial neural network based approaches. We begin tackling the scientifically existential challenge of Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) detection by deploying deep Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) on resource-constrained neuromorphic hardware. Our approach partitions large, pre-trained networks onto SynSense Xylo hardware using maximal splitting, a novel greedy algorithm. We validate this pipeline with on-chip power measurements, achieving instrument-scaled inference at 100mW. While our full-scale SNN achieves state-of-the-art accuracy among SNN baselines, our experiments reveal a more important insight that a smaller un-partitioned model significantly outperforms larger, split models. This finding highlights that hardware co-design is paramount for optimal performance. Our work thus provides a practical deployment blueprint, a key insight into the challenges of model scaling, and reinforces radio astronomy as a demanding yet ideal domain for advancing applied neuromorphic computing.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses real-time, energy-efficient Radio Frequency Interference detection for radio astronomy using Spiking Neural Networks deployed on neuromorphic hardware.
AI.motivation: The rapid increase in data rates from upcoming radio telescope observatories necessitates energy-efficient, real-time artificial intelligence methods for processing this data.
AI.method: The paper employs Spiking Neural Networks partitioned by a novel greedy algorithm onto SynSense Xylo hardware for inference, validating the framework through power measurements and accuracy evaluation.
AI.result: Inference on neuromorphic hardware achieves 100mW scaled power consumption and competitive state-of-the-art accuracy for SNNs, with insights showing smaller un-partitioned models perform better.
AI.conclusion: This work demonstrates model-hardware co-design as essential for optimal performance in neuromorphic computing and offers insights and practical frameworks for advancing radio astronomy applications.

title: I've Changed My Mind: Robots Adapting to Changing Human Goals during Collaboration
summary: For effective human-robot collaboration, a robot must align its actions with human goals, even as they change mid-task. Prior approaches often assume fixed goals, reducing goal prediction to a one-time inference. However, in real-world scenarios, humans frequently shift goals, making it challenging for robots to adapt without explicit communication. We propose a method for detecting goal changes by tracking multiple candidate action sequences and verifying their plausibility against a policy bank. Upon detecting a change, the robot refines its belief in relevant past actions and constructs Receding Horizon Planning (RHP) trees to actively select actions that assist the human while encouraging Differentiating Actions to reveal their updated goal. We evaluate our approach in a collaborative cooking environment with up to 30 unique recipes and compare it to three comparable human goal prediction algorithms. Our method outperforms all baselines, quickly converging to the correct goal after a switch, reducing task completion time, and improving collaboration efficiency.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method to enable robots to detect and adapt to changes in human goals during collaboration. Using a combination of Receding Horizon Planning and Differentiating Actions, the method outperforms others in efficiency and goal recognition.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the challenge of robots adapting to human goal changes mid-task in real-world collaboration scenarios. Existing methods assume fixed goals, which does not align with human behavior.
AI.method: The authors propose tracking multiple candidate action sequences and using a policy bank to detect goal changes. Upon detection, they refine the robot's belief system, use Receding Horizon Planning trees, and strategically employ Differentiating Actions to glean the updated goal.
AI.result: The proposed method was evaluated in a collaborative cooking environment with 30 unique recipes. It outperformed three existing human goal prediction algorithms in terms of goal alignment, task completion speed, and collaboration efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Integrating the proposed method into robots enhances adaptability in dynamic human-robot collaborations. This improves efficiency and responsiveness, paving the way for better human-robot teaming in practical settings.

title: Chorex: Restartable, Language-Integrated Choreographies
summary: We built Chorex, a language that brings choreographic programming to Elixir as a path toward robust distributed applications. Chorex is unique among choreographic languages because it tolerates failure among actors: when an actor crashes, Chorex spawns a new process, restores state using a checkpoint, and updates the network configuration for all actors. Chorex also proves that full-featured choreographies can be implemented via metaprogramming, and that doing so achieves tight integration with the host language. For example, mismatches between choreography requirements and an actor implementation are reported statically and in terms of source code rather than macro-expanded code. This paper illustrates Chorex on several examples, ranging from a higher-order bookseller to a secure remote password protocol, details its implementation, and measures the overhead of checkpointing. We conjecture that Chorex's projection strategy, which outputs sets of stateless functions, is a viable approach for other languages to support restartable actors.

AI.tldr: Chorex is a choreographic programming language for Elixir that addresses actor failure using checkpointing, process restoration, and network reconfiguration.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to create a robust choreographic programming language integrated with Elixir, addressing failure tolerance in distributed systems.
AI.method: Chorex uses metaprogramming to implement choreographies, ensuring integration with the host language and allowing static reporting of mismatches.
AI.result: Chorex demonstrates practical applications such as bookseller and secure password protocols, evaluates checkpointing performance, and offers insights for applying this projection strategy to other languages.
AI.conclusion: Chorex provides a novel approach for fault-tolerant distributed applications, enabling integration with host languages and showcasing a sustainable projection strategy for restartable actors.

title: From generative AI to the brain: five takeaways
comment: Frontiers in Computational Neuroscience, in press
summary: The big strides seen in generative AI are not based on somewhat obscure algorithms, but due to clearly defined generative principles. The resulting concrete implementations have proven themselves in large numbers of applications. We suggest that it is imperative to thoroughly investigate which of these generative principles may be operative also in the brain, and hence relevant for cognitive neuroscience. In addition, ML research led to a range of interesting characterizations of neural information processing systems. We discuss five examples, the shortcomings of world modelling, the generation of thought processes, attention, neural scaling laws, and quantization, that illustrate how much neuroscience could potentially learn from ML research.

AI.tldr: Investigating generative AI principles in cognitive neuroscience could enhance understanding of brain functions.
AI.motivation: To bridge the advancements in generative AI and their potential applications in understanding neural mechanisms in the brain.
AI.method: Examining five key concepts from machine learning: world modeling, thought process generation, attention, neural scaling laws, and quantization.
AI.result: Illustrates how cognitive neuroscience could gain insights from machine learning research.
AI.conclusion: Understanding generative AI principles could unlock deeper knowledge in neuroscience, suggesting a symbiotic relationship between the disciplines.

title: Rethinking Kernel Program Repair: Benchmarking and Enhancing LLMs with RGym
comment: 39th Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2025) Workshop: Evaluating the Evolving LLM Lifecycle: Benchmarks, Emergent Abilities, and Scaling
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have revolutionized automated program repair (APR) but current benchmarks like SWE-Bench predominantly focus on userspace applications and overlook the complexities of kernel-space debugging and repair. The Linux kernel poses unique challenges due to its monolithic structure, concurrency, and low-level hardware interactions. Prior efforts such as KGym and CrashFixer have highlighted the difficulty of APR in this domain, reporting low success rates or relying on costly and complex pipelines and pricey cloud infrastructure. In this work, we introduce RGym, a lightweight, platform-agnostic APR evaluation framework for the Linux kernel designed to operate on local commodity hardware. Built on RGym, we propose a simple yet effective APR pipeline leveraging specialized localization techniques (e.g., call stacks and blamed commits) to overcome the unrealistic usage of oracles in KGym. We test on a filtered and verified dataset of 143 bugs. Our method achieves up to a 43.36% pass rate with GPT-5 Thinking while maintaining a cost of under $0.20 per bug. We further conduct an ablation study to analyze contributions from our proposed localization strategy, prompt structure, and model choice, and demonstrate that feedback-based retries can significantly enhance success rates.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces RGym, a novel evaluation framework designed for efficient automated program repair (APR) in the Linux kernel domain, overcoming limitations of previous approaches.
AI.motivation: Current APR benchmarks lack focus on kernel-space challenges, limiting progress in Linux kernel debugging and repair.
AI.method: RGym framework utilizes specialized localization techniques, a filtered dataset, and employs feedback-based retries with GPT models to enhance APR success.
AI.result: The proposed method achieves up to a 43.36% pass rate at low costs, demonstrating improvement over existing efforts.
AI.conclusion: RGym offers a scalable, cost-effective solution for APR in kernel-space with enhanced results using tailored strategies.

title: Graph-Memoized Reasoning: Foundations Structured Workflow Reuse in Intelligent Systems
summary:
Modern large language model-based reasoning systems frequently recompute similar reasoning steps across tasks, wasting computational resources, inflating inference latency, and limiting reproducibility. These inefficiencies underscore the need for persistent reasoning mechanisms that can recall and reuse prior computational traces.
  We introduce Graph-Memoized Reasoning, a formal framework for representing, storing, and reusing reasoning workflows as graph-structured memory. By encoding past decision graphs and retrieving them through structural and semantic similarity, our approach enables compositional reuse of subgraphs across new reasoning tasks.
  We formulate an optimization objective that minimizes total reasoning cost regularized by inconsistency between stored and generated workflows, providing a theoretical foundation for efficiency-consistency trade-offs in intelligent systems. We outline a conceptual evaluation protocol aligned with the proposed optimization objective.
  This framework establishes the groundwork for interpretable, cost-efficient, and self-improving reasoning architectures, offering a step toward persistent memory in large-scale agentic systems.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a framework for using graph-structured memory to store and reuse reasoning workflows, reducing redundancy and improving efficiency in language models.
AI.motivation: Current reasoning systems often recompute similar processes, leading to inefficiency, high computational costs, and limited reproducibility.
AI.method: The authors propose 'Graph-Memoized Reasoning' which encodes decision graphs and retrieves them using structural and semantic similarity. They include an optimization objective to balance reasoning cost and inconsistency.
AI.result: The framework allows for compositional reuse of reasoning subgraphs, with theoretical provisions for evaluating efficiency and consistency trade-offs.
AI.conclusion: This approach paves the way for interpretable and efficient reasoning systems, introducing persistent memory for large-scale models.

title: Angular Graph Fractional Fourier Transform: Theory and Application
summary: Graph spectral representations are fundamental in graph signal processing, offering a rigorous framework for analyzing and processing graph-structured data. The graph fractional Fourier transform (GFRFT) extends the classical graph Fourier transform (GFT) with a fractional-order parameter, enabling flexible spectral analysis while preserving mathematical consistency. The angular graph Fourier transform (AGFT) introduces angular control via GFT eigenvector rotation; however, existing constructions fail to degenerate to the GFT at zero angle, which is a critical flaw that undermines theoretical consistency and interpretability. To resolve these complementary limitations - GFRFT's lack of angular regulation and AGFT's defective degeneracy - this study proposes an angular GFRFT (AGFRFT), a unified framework that integrates fractional-order and angular spectral analyses with theoretical rigor. A degeneracy-friendly rotation matrix family ensures exact GFT degeneration at zero angle, with two AGFRFT variants (I-AGFRFT and II-AGFRFT) defined accordingly. Rigorous theoretical analyses confirm their unitarity, invertibility, and smooth parameter dependence. Both support learnable joint parameterization of the angle and fractional order, enabling adaptive spectral processing for diverse graph signals. Extensive experiments on real-world data denoising, image denoising, and point cloud denoising demonstrate that AGFRFT outperforms GFRFT and AGFT in terms of spectral concentration, reconstruction quality, and controllable spectral manipulation, establishing a robust and flexible tool for integrated angular fractional spectral analysis in graph signal processing.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Angular Graph Fractional Fourier Transform (AGFRFT) to combine fractional-order and angular spectral analysis in a consistent and efficient framework.
AI.motivation: Current graph spectral analysis methods have shortcomings: GFRFT lacks angular regulation, while AGFT fails to degrade to GFT at zero angle, affecting theoretical consistency.
AI.method: The authors propose AGFRFT with a generative rotation matrix ensuring exact GFT degeneration at zero angle. Two versions, I-AGFRFT and II-AGFRFT, with learnable parameters, are designed for joint angular and fractional-order spectral processing.
AI.result: The AGFRFT is theoretically proven to be unitary, invertible, and smoothly parameter-dependent. Experiments show its superior performance in spectral concentration, reconstruction, and spectral manipulation for various real-world applications.
AI.conclusion: The AGFRFT framework effectively resolves limitations in existing graph spectral methods and offers a robust tool for adaptive and hybrid spectral analysis, outperforming existing models in practical tasks.

title: EfficientSAM3: Progressive Hierarchical Distillation for Video Concept Segmentation from SAM1, 2, and 3
summary: The Segment Anything Model 3 (SAM3) advances visual understanding with Promptable Concept Segmentation (PCS) across images and videos, but its unified architecture (shared vision backbone, DETR-style detector, dense-memory tracker) remains prohibitive for on-device use. We present EfficientSAM3, a family of efficient models built on Progressive Hierarchical Distillation (PHD) that transfers capability from SAM3 to lightweight students in three stages: (1) Encoder Distillation aligns image features via prompt-in-the-loop training on SA-1B; (2) Temporal Memory Distillation replaces dense memory with a compact Perceiver-based module trained on SA-V to compress and retrieve spatiotemporal features efficiently; and (3) End-to-End Fine-Tuning refines the full pipeline on the official SAM3 PCS data to preserve concept-level performance. PHD yields a spectrum of student variants using RepViT, TinyViT, and EfficientViT backbones, enabling on-device concept segmentation and tracking while maintaining high fidelity to teacher behavior. We benchmark on popular VOS datasets, and compare with varies of releated work, achieing strong performance-efficiency trade-offs.

AI.tldr: EfficientSAM3 is a family of lightweight models based on Progressive Hierarchical Distillation (PHD) transferring capabilities from the heavyweight SAM3 for on-device concept segmentation and tracking.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address the challenge of making the SAM3 architecture suitable for on-device use, as its original unified design is computationally prohibitive.
AI.method: The method, Progressive Hierarchical Distillation (PHD), transfers SAM3's capabilities to lighter models in three stages: Encoder Distillation for image feature alignment, Temporal Memory Distillation for spatiotemporal compression, and End-to-End Fine-Tuning for preserving performance.
AI.result: EfficientSAM3 employs various light backbones (RepViT, TinyViT, EfficientViT), achieving high fidelity to the original while offering improved efficiency for on-device functionalities. It achieves strong performance-efficiency trade-offs.
AI.conclusion: EfficientSAM3 successfully introduces efficient, lightweight versions of SAM3 via PHD, enabling practical use in resource-constrained environments while maintaining strong conceptual segmentation and tracking performance.

title: Connecting the Dots: A Machine Learning Ready Dataset for Ionospheric Forecasting Models
comment: 8 pages, 2 figures, 2 tables. Accepted as a poster presentation in the Machine Learning for the Physical Sciences workshop at NeurIPS 2025
summary: Operational forecasting of the ionosphere remains a critical space weather challenge due to sparse observations, complex coupling across geospatial layers, and a growing need for timely, accurate predictions that support Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS), communications, aviation safety, as well as satellite operations. As part of the 2025 NASA Heliolab, we present a curated, open-access dataset that integrates diverse ionospheric and heliospheric measurements into a coherent, machine learning-ready structure, designed specifically to support next-generation forecasting models and address gaps in current operational frameworks. Our workflow integrates a large selection of data sources comprising Solar Dynamic Observatory data, solar irradiance indices (F10.7), solar wind parameters (velocity and interplanetary magnetic field), geomagnetic activity indices (Kp, AE, SYM-H), and NASA JPL's Global Ionospheric Maps of Total Electron Content (GIM-TEC). We also implement geospatially sparse data such as the TEC derived from the World-Wide GNSS Receiver Network and crowdsourced Android smartphone measurements. This novel heterogeneous dataset is temporally and spatially aligned into a single, modular data structure that supports both physical and data-driven modeling. Leveraging this dataset, we train and benchmark several spatiotemporal machine learning architectures for forecasting vertical TEC under both quiet and geomagnetically active conditions. This work presents an extensive dataset and modeling pipeline that enables exploration of not only ionospheric dynamics but also broader Sun-Earth interactions, supporting both scientific inquiry and operational forecasting efforts.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a curated and open-access machine learning-ready dataset aimed at improving ionospheric forecasting for space weather, incorporating diverse measurements and geospatial data for modeling global ionospheric dynamics.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address critical challenges in operational ionospheric forecasting due to sparse observations, complex geospatial coupling, and growing demands for accurate predictions essential for GNSS, aviation, communication, and satellite operations.
AI.method: A large and diverse dataset is curated using multiple sources including solar and geomagnetic indices, GNSS data, TEC measurements, and more, integrated into a unified structure for forecasting models. Machine learning architectures are trained and benchmarked for these applications.
AI.result: A novel dataset that aligns temporally and spatially diverse measurements was developed. Machine learning models were successfully trained to forecast ionospheric variables under different conditions, demonstrating the potential of this integrated approach.
AI.conclusion: The dataset and modeling workflow advance both scientific understanding of Sun-Earth interactions and operational forecasting capabilities, providing resources for next-generation models and broader space weather applications.

title: Mind the Motions: Benchmarking Theory-of-Mind in Everyday Body Language
summary: Our ability to interpret others' mental states through nonverbal cues (NVCs) is fundamental to our survival and social cohesion. While existing Theory of Mind (ToM) benchmarks have primarily focused on false-belief tasks and reasoning with asymmetric information, they overlook other mental states beyond belief and the rich tapestry of human nonverbal communication. We present Motion2Mind, a framework for evaluating the ToM capabilities of machines in interpreting NVCs. Leveraging an expert-curated body-language reference as a proxy knowledge base, we build Motion2Mind, a carefully curated video dataset with fine-grained nonverbal cue annotations paired with manually verified psychological interpretations. It encompasses 222 types of nonverbal cues and 397 mind states. Our evaluation reveals that current AI systems struggle significantly with NVC interpretation, exhibiting not only a substantial performance gap in Detection, as well as patterns of over-interpretation in Explanation compared to human annotators.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces Motion2Mind, a framework and dataset for evaluating AI's Theory of Mind capabilities through nonverbal cue interpretation, showing AI's challenges with detection and explanation.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks for Theory of Mind focus on false-belief tasks and asymmetric information but neglect other mental states and nonverbal communication, which are crucial for social understanding.
AI.method: The authors developed Motion2Mind, a dataset of videos annotated with nonverbal cues and psychological interpretations, using an expert-curated body-language knowledge base.
AI.result: Current AI systems struggle to interpret nonverbal cues effectively, showing poor detection performance and over-interpretation tendencies in explanations compared to humans.
AI.conclusion: AI systems are significantly limited in interpreting nonverbal cues, underscoring the need for further advancement in this area to bridge the gap between human and machine understanding.

title: LLM4EO: Large Language Model for Evolutionary Optimization in Flexible Job Shop Scheduling
summary: Customized static operator design has enabled widespread application of Evolutionary Algorithms (EAs), but their search performance is transient during iterations and prone to degradation. Dynamic operators aim to address this but typically rely on predefined designs and localized parameter control during the search process, lacking adaptive optimization throughout evolution. To overcome these limitations, this work leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) to perceive evolutionary dynamics and enable operator-level meta-evolution. The proposed framework, LLMs for Evolutionary Optimization (LLM4EO), comprises three components: knowledge-transfer-based operator design, evolution perception and analysis, and adaptive operator evolution. Firstly, initialization of operators is performed by transferring the strengths of classical operators via LLMs. Then, search preferences and potential limitations of operators are analyzed by integrating fitness performance and evolutionary features, accompanied by corresponding suggestions for improvement. Upon stagnation of population evolution, gene selection priorities of operators are dynamically optimized via improvement prompting strategies. This approach achieves co-evolution of populations and operators in the search, introducing a novel paradigm for enhancing the efficiency and adaptability of EAs. Finally, a series of validations on multiple benchmark datasets of the flexible job shop scheduling problem demonstrate that LLM4EO accelerates population evolution and outperforms both mainstream evolutionary programming and traditional EAs.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new framework called LLM4EO utilizing Large Language Models (LLMs) to address limitations in Evolutionary Algorithms (EAs) by enabling dynamic, adaptive operator evolution for improved search efficiency.
AI.motivation: Traditional Evolutionary Algorithms rely on static operator designs that degrade performance over time, and dynamic operators are limited by predefined designs and localized control without adaptive capabilities throughout evolution.
AI.method: LLM4EO integrates LLMs for three key components: initializing operators via classical operator knowledge transfer, analyzing fitness performance and evolutionary features for operator improvement, and dynamically optimizing operators using improvement prompts during population stagnation.
AI.result: LLM4EO enhances co-evolution of populations and operators, accelerates population evolution, and surpasses mainstream evolutionary programming and traditional EAs in benchmark tests.
AI.conclusion: The framework introduces a new paradigm for improving adaptability and efficiency in Evolutionary Algorithms, demonstrating superior performance in complex scheduling problems such as flexible job shop scheduling.

title: The Role of Consequential and Functional Sound in Human-Robot Interaction: Toward Audio Augmented Reality Interfaces
summary: As robots become increasingly integrated into everyday environments, understanding how they communicate with humans is critical. Sound offers a powerful channel for interaction, encompassing both operational noises and intentionally designed auditory cues. In this study, we examined the effects of consequential and functional sounds on human perception and behavior, including a novel exploration of spatial sound through localization and handover tasks. Results show that consequential sounds of the Kinova Gen3 manipulator did not negatively affect perceptions, spatial localization is highly accurate for lateral cues but declines for frontal cues, and spatial sounds can simultaneously convey task-relevant information while promoting warmth and reducing discomfort. These findings highlight the potential of functional and transformative auditory design to enhance human-robot collaboration and inform future sound-based interaction strategies.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how robots can use sounds to enhance communication and collaboration with humans, particularly focusing on spatial auditory cues.
AI.motivation: Understanding robot-human communication is crucial as robots become part of daily environments, and sound is a key channel for interaction.
AI.method: The study evaluates human perception of robot sounds, tests spatial auditory cues in localization and handover tasks, and analyzes the effects on comfort and task efficiency.
AI.result: Kinova Gen3 manipulator sounds did not hinder perceptions, spatial localization was highly accurate for some cues but less so for others, and spatial sounds improved task communication while reducing discomfort.
AI.conclusion: Functional auditory design can improve human-robot collaboration and contribute to future sound-based interaction strategies.

title: BlueScript: A Disaggregated Virtual Machine for Microcontrollers
summary:
Virtual machines (VMs) are highly beneficial for microcontroller development. 
In particular, interactive programming environments greatly facilitate iterative development processes, 
and higher execution speeds expand the range of applications that can be developed. 
However, due to their limited memory size, microcontroller VMs provide a limited set of features. 
Widely used VMs for microcontrollers often lack interactive responsiveness and/or high execution speed. 
While researchers have investigated offloading certain VM components to other machines,the types of components that can be offloaded are still restricted. 
In this paper, we propose a disaggregated VM that offloads as many components as possible to a host machine. 
This makes it possible to exploit the abundant memory of the host machine and its powerful processing capability to provide rich features through the VM. 
As an instance of a disaggregated VM, we design and implement a BlueScript VM. 
The BlueScript VM is a virtual machine for microcontrollers that provides an interactive development environment. 
We offload most of the components of the BlueScript VM to a host machine. 
To reduce communication overhead between the host machine and the microcontroller,  
we employed a data structure called a shadow machine on the host machine, 
which mirrors the execution state of the microcontroller. 
Through our experiments, we confirmed that offloading components does not seriously compromise their expected benefits.  
We assess that an offloaded incremental compiler results in faster execution speed than MicroPython and Espruino,  
while keeping interactivity comparable with MicroPython.  
In addition, our experiments observe that the offloaded dynamic compiler improves VM performance. 
Through this investigation, we demonstrate the feasibility of providing rich features even on VMs for memory-limited microcontrollers.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a disaggregated virtual machine (VM) for microcontrollers, offloading components to a host machine to provide enhanced features, performance, and interactivity.
AI.motivation: Microcontroller VMs often lack interactive responsiveness and high execution speeds due to limited memory size, restricting their features and development possibilities.
AI.method: The authors designed and implemented BlueScript VM, an interactive VM for microcontrollers, which utilizes a shadow machine on a host machine to reduce communication overhead while offloading components.
AI.result: Experiments showed that offloading components improved features and execution speed (faster than MicroPython and Espruino) without compromising interactivity or performance.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates the feasibility of creating feature-rich VMs for memory-limited microcontrollers by offloading VM components to a host machine.

title: Mesoscale tissue properties and electric fields in brain stimulation - bridging the macroscopic and microscopic scales
comment: 16 pages, 1 main figure, 6 appendix figures and 4 appendix tables
summary: Accurate simulations of electric fields (E-fields) in brain stimulation depend on tissue conductivity representations that link macroscopic assumptions with underlying microscopic tissue structure. Mesoscale conductivity variations can produce meaningful changes in E-fields and neural activation thresholds but remain largely absent from standard macroscopic models. Recent microscopic models have suggested substantial local E-field perturbations and could, in principle, inform mesoscale conductivity. However, the quantitative validity of microscopic models is limited by fixation-related tissue distortion and incomplete extracellular-space reconstruction. We outline approaches that bridge macro- and microscales to derive consistent mesoscale conductivity distributions, providing a foundation for accurate multiscale models of E-fields and neural activation in brain stimulation.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses improving electric field simulations in brain stimulation by integrating mesoscale conductivity variations and bridging macro- and microscopic tissue models.
AI.motivation: To enhance the accuracy of brain stimulation models by addressing the lack of mesoscale conductivity variations in standard macroscopic models.
AI.method: Proposes bridging macro- and microscopic scales using mesoscale conductivity distributions, while addressing limitations like tissue distortion and incomplete extracellular-space data.
AI.result: Approach generates more accurate mesoscale conductivity distributions for multiscale E-field modeling.
AI.conclusion: The methods provide a foundation for precise simulations of electric fields and neural activation, advancing brain stimulation research.

title: A Causal Perspective on Measuring, Explaining and Mitigating Smells in \llm-Generated Code
summary:
Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have accelerated their adoption in software engineering contexts. However, concerns persist about the structural quality of the code they produce. In particular, LLMs often replicate poor coding practices, introducing code smells (i.e., patterns that hinder readability, maintainability, or design integrity). Although prior research has examined the detection or repair of smells, we still lack a clear understanding of how and when these issues emerge in generated code.
  This paper addresses this gap by systematically measuring, explaining and mitigating smell propensity in LLM-generated code. We build on the Propensity Smelly Score (PSC), a probabilistic metric that estimates the likelihood of generating particular smell types, and establish its robustness as a signal of structural quality. Using PSC as an instrument for causal analysis, we identify how generation strategy, model size, model architecture and prompt formulation shape the structural properties of generated code. Our findings show that prompt design and architectural choices play a decisive role in smell propensity and motivate practical mitigation strategies that reduce its occurrence. A user study further demonstrates that PSC helps developers interpret model behavior and assess code quality, providing evidence that smell propensity signals can support human judgement. Taken together, our work lays the groundwork for integrating quality-aware assessments into the evaluation and deployment of LLMs for code.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates structural quality issues in code generated by LLMs, focusing on code smells. It proposes a probabilistic metric (PSC) to measure and mitigate smell propensity.
AI.motivation: To understand and address the emergence of code smells in LLM-generated software and ensure better structural quality in generated code.
AI.method: The authors proposed the Propensity Smelly Score (PSC) as a probabilistic metric, conducted causal analysis on factors affecting smell propensity, and validated PSC through a user study.
AI.result: The study showed that prompt design and architecture significantly influence smell propensity, while PSC aids developers in interpreting model behavior and assessing code quality.
AI.conclusion: This work establishes a foundation for integrating smell propensity assessments into LLM evaluations, highlighting effective mitigation strategies for improving code quality.

title: MACIE: Multi-Agent Causal Intelligence Explainer for Collective Behavior Understanding
summary: As Multi Agent Reinforcement Learning systems are used in safety critical applications. Understanding why agents make decisions and how they achieve collective behavior is crucial. Existing explainable AI methods struggle in multi agent settings. They fail to attribute collective outcomes to individuals, quantify emergent behaviors, or capture complex interactions. We present MACIE Multi Agent Causal Intelligence Explainer, a framework combining structural causal models, interventional counterfactuals, and Shapley values to provide comprehensive explanations. MACIE addresses three questions. First, each agent's causal contribution using interventional attribution scores. Second, system level emergent intelligence through synergy metrics separating collective effects from individual contributions. Third, actionable explanations using natural language narratives synthesizing causal insights. We evaluate MACIE across four MARL scenarios: cooperative, competitive, and mixed motive. Results show accurate outcome attribution, mean phi_i equals 5.07, standard deviation less than 0.05, detection of positive emergence in cooperative tasks, synergy index up to 0.461, and efficient computation, 0.79 seconds per dataset on CPU. MACIE uniquely combines causal rigor, emergence quantification, and multi agent support while remaining practical for real time use. This represents a step toward interpretable, trustworthy, and accountable multi agent AI.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MACIE, a framework to explain collective behaviors and decisions in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) systems using causal methods and Shapley values.
AI.motivation: There is a need for effective explanations in safety-critical MARL systems to understand agent behaviors, collective outcomes, emergent behaviors, and complex interactions, which existing explainable AI techniques fail to achieve.
AI.method: The proposed framework, MACIE, combines structural causal models, interventional counterfactuals, and Shapley values. It assesses individual agent contributions, system-level emergent intelligence, and provides actionable explanations via natural language narratives.
AI.result: In tests across cooperative, competitive, and mixed motive MARL scenarios, MACIE demonstrated accurate outcome attribution, detection of emergent intelligence, and efficient computation—all in real-time.
AI.conclusion: MACIE offers a practical, rigorous, and comprehensive framework for trustworthy and interpretable multi-agent AI systems.

title: Spectral Identifiability for Interpretable Probe Geometry
summary: Linear probes are widely used to interpret and evaluate neural representations, yet their reliability remains unclear, as probes may appear accurate in some regimes but collapse unpredictably in others. We uncover a spectral mechanism behind this phenomenon and formalize it as the Spectral Identifiability Principle (SIP), a verifiable Fisher-inspired condition for probe stability. When the eigengap separating task-relevant directions is larger than the Fisher estimation error, the estimated subspace concentrates and accuracy remains consistent, whereas closing this gap induces instability in a phase-transition manner. Our analysis connects eigengap geometry, sample size, and misclassification risk through finite-sample reasoning, providing an interpretable diagnostic rather than a loose generalization bound. Controlled synthetic studies, where Fisher quantities are computed exactly, confirm these predictions and show how spectral inspection can anticipate unreliable probes before they distort downstream evaluation.
